name: housing
content:
housing

noun
 
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1.  
     [uncountable] houses, flats, etc. that people live in, especially when referring to their type, price or condition
    • rental/student housing
    • temporary/permanent housing
    • low-cost/cheap housing
    • There is an urgent need to build more affordable housing.
    • We must find a way to solve the city's housing crisis.
    • The study linked poor housing conditions to a variety of health problems.
    • How severe is the housing shortage in Hong Kong?
    • the housing market (= the activity of buying and selling houses, etc.)
    • The low interest rate has triggered a housing bubble (= a period of time when house prices increase quickly, but which is unlikely to last long).
    see also affordable housing, public housing, sheltered housing, social housing
    Extra Examples
    • Many health problems are made worse by inadequate housing.
    • Many new housing developments had sprung up around the city.
    • She receives a substantial housing allowance on top of her salary.
    • The aim of the scheme was to provide good low-cost housing for workers.
    • The area is dominated by terraced housing.
    • They provide good low-cost housing for workers.
    • Too many families are still living in substandard housing.
    • What happens when the housing boom finally slows?
    • The housing market has had a good year.
    Topics Houses and homesb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • affordable
    • cheap
    • good
    • …
    verb + housing
    • build
    • provide
    housing + noun
    • association
    • authority
    • committee
    • …
    preposition
    • in… housing
    See full entry
  2.  
     [uncountable] the job of providing houses, flats, etc. for people to live in
    • Tenants may only keep pets with the written consent of the housing department.
    • They discussed how the council's housing policy could be changed to deal with the growing housing crisis.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • affordable
    • cheap
    • good
    • …
    verb + housing
    • build
    • provide
    housing + noun
    • association
    • authority
    • committee
    • …
    preposition
    • in… housing
    See full entry
  3. [countable] a hard cover that protects part of a machine
    • a car’s rear axle housing
See housing in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee housing in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: house
content:
house

verb
 
 
/haʊz/
 
/haʊz/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they house
 
/haʊz/
 
/haʊz/
he / she / it houses
 
/ˈhaʊzɪz/
 
/ˈhaʊzɪz/
past simple housed
 
/haʊzd/
 
/haʊzd/
past participle housed
 
/haʊzd/
 
/haʊzd/
-ing form housing
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
jump to other results

    provide home

  1.  
     house somebody to provide a place for a person or an animal to live
    • The government is committed to housing the refugees.
    • He can barely afford to feed, clothe and house his family.
    • People whose homes were flooded were temporarily housed in community centres.
    • The prison normally houses about 200 medium-security prisoners.
    Extra Examples
    • At no time in the 19th century were the working classes adequately housed.
    • The losers in this society are the homeless and badly housed.
    • The fish can be temporarily housed in a smaller aquarium.
    • The rabbits were housed individually.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • permanently
    • temporarily
    • individually
    • …
    See full entry
    2.

    keep something

  2.  
     house something to be the place where something is kept or where something operates from
    • The library houses a collection of 15 000 books.
    • The gallery houses 2 000 works of modern art.
    • The building also houses the offices of the District Medical Officer.
    • be housed in something The museum is housed in the Old Court House.
    • be housed at something Most film material housed at the Irish Film Archive is in English.
    Extra Examples
    • The new offices will house 600 administration staff.
    • The books were housed in glass-fronted cases.
    • These offices also house a printing firm.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • permanently
    • temporarily
    • individually
    • …
    See full entry
    3. Word OriginOld English hūs (noun), hūsian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch huis, German Haus (nouns), and Dutch huizen, German hausen (verbs).
See house in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee house in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: house
relatives: not a dry eye in the house
get on like a house on fire
eat somebody out of house and home

name: housing benefit
content:
housing benefit

noun
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ benɪfɪt/
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ benɪfɪt/
 [uncountable, countable]
jump to other results
  1. (in the UK) money given by the government to people who do not earn much, to help them pay for a place to live in
    • to be eligible for housing benefit
    • to be on housing benefit
    • to claim housing benefit
    • I received housing benefit when I was unemployed.
    Topics Houses and homesc2, Social issuesc2
Check pronunciation: housing benefit

name: housing estate
content:
housing estate

noun
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ ɪsteɪt/
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ ɪsteɪt/
 (British English)
(also housing development North American English, British English)
jump to other results
  1. an area in which a large number of houses or flats are planned and built together at the same time
    • They live on a housing estate.
    Topics Houses and homesb2

name: housing project
content:
housing project

noun
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ prɒdʒekt/
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ prɑːdʒekt/
(also project)
jump to other results
  1. a group of houses or apartments built for poor families, usually with government money
    • She lives in a housing project on the edge of town.
    compare housing scheme (2)Topics Social issuesc2
See housing project in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: housing project

name: housing scheme
content:
housing scheme

noun
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ skiːm/
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ skiːm/
 (British English)
jump to other results
  1. a project, often funded by a local council or another organization, that provides homes for people to buy or rent at a low price
    • The council has proposed plans for an affordable housing scheme.
    Topics Houses and homesc1
  2. (Scottish English, informal scheme)
     an area of social housing (= houses or flats for people to rent or buy at low prices)
    • Over 200 new properties have been built in the housing scheme.
    compare housing projectTopics Houses and homesc2
Check pronunciation: housing scheme

name: public housing
content:
public housing

noun
 
/ˌpʌblɪk ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 
/ˌpʌblɪk ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 [uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. (in the US) houses and flats that are built by the government for people who do not have enough money to pay for private accommodation
    • Public housing is limited to low-income families and individuals.
    • There has been massive investment in public housing.
    compare social housingTopics Houses and homesc1, Social issuesc1
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryPublic housing is used before these nouns:
    • tenant
    See full entry
See public housing in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: public housing

name: sheltered housing
content:
sheltered housing

noun
 
/ˌʃeltəd ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 
/ˌʃeltərd ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 [uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. (in Britain) houses or flats that are designed and built for elderly people or for people with disabilities so that they can live in the local community instead of in hospitals or care homes. Sheltered housing is usually arranged in small blocks, with a person in each block whose job is to help the people living there. The term is less often used in the US for this type of housing.
    • sheltered housing for older people
    • The new sheltered housing project will be built close to the shops and main bus routes.
    Topics Disabilityc2
Check pronunciation: sheltered housing

name: social housing
content:
social housing

noun
 
/ˌsəʊʃl ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 
/ˌsəʊʃl ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 [uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. (in the UK) houses or flats that are provided by a local council or another organization for people on low incomes to buy or rent at a low price
    • Public expenditure on social housing provision has doubled in the last five years.
    compare affordable housing, public housingTopics Houses and homesc1, Social issuesc1
Check pronunciation: social housing

name: affordable housing
content:
affordable housing

noun
 
/əˌfɔːdəbl ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 
/əˌfɔːrdəbl ˈhaʊzɪŋ/
 [uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. houses or flats that are available for people on low incomes to buy or rent at a low price, especially because the government has required house-building companies to offer a certain number of new properties at lower prices
    • The city needs more affordable housing for families on low incomes.
    • The shortage of affordable housing has caused an increase in the number of homeless people.
    compare social housingTopics Houses and homesc1, Social issuesc1
Check pronunciation: affordable housing

name: housing association
content:
housing association

noun
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ əsəʊsieɪʃn/,
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ əsəʊʃieɪʃn/
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ əsəʊsieɪʃn/,
 
/ˈhaʊzɪŋ əsəʊʃieɪʃn/
jump to other results
  1. (in the UK) an organization that owns houses, flats, etc. and helps people to rent or buy them at a low price
    CultureHousing associations will share the cost of houses with people who cannot afford to buy a house on their own. In the US, advice and financial help with buying a home comes from the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
    Topics Social issuesc2
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryHousing association is used before these nouns:
    • tenant
    See full entry
Check pronunciation: housing association

name: the Federal Housing Administration
content:
the Federal Housing Administration

 
/ðə ˌfedərəl ˈhaʊzɪŋ ədmɪnɪstreɪʃn/
 
/ðə ˌfedərəl ˈhaʊzɪŋ ədmɪnɪstreɪʃn/
(abbreviation the FHA)
jump to other results
  1. the US government organization that was started in 1934 to allow more people to buy houses. The FHA provides insurance for mortgages and is part of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Check pronunciation: the Federal Housing Administration

name: the Department of Housing and Urban Development
content:
the Department of Housing and Urban Development

 
/ðə dɪˌpɑːtmənt əv ˌhaʊzɪŋ ən ˌɜːbən dɪˈveləpmənt/
 
/ðə dɪˌpɑːrtmənt əv ˌhaʊzɪŋ ən ˌɜːrbən dɪˈveləpmənt/
(abbreviation HUD)
jump to other results
  1. the US government department in charge of financial programmes to build houses and to help people buy their own homes. It provides insurance for mortgages and helps pay for houses for poor and old people. It also plans the development of cities.
Check pronunciation: the Department of Housing and Urban Development
nearBys: the Department of Health & Social Care
the Department of Housing and Urban Development

name: the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government
content:
the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government

 
/ðə ˌmɪnɪstri əv ˌhaʊzɪŋ kəˌmjuːnətiz ən ˌləʊkl ˈɡʌvənmənt/
 
/ðə ˌmɪnɪstri əv ˌhaʊzɪŋ kəˌmjuːnətiz ən ˌləʊkl ˈɡʌvərnmənt/
jump to other results
  1. the British government department responsible for policy on government at local level, on housing and on public services. It was formed in 2006 as the Department for Communities and Local Government. In 2018 it became the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government.
Check pronunciation: the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government
nearBys: the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government

name: project
content:
project

noun
 OPAL W
 
/ˈprɒdʒekt/
 
/ˈprɑːdʒekt/
jump to other results

    school/college work

  1.  
     a piece of work involving careful study of a subject over a period of time, done by school or college students
    • a history project
    • project on something My class is doing a project on medieval towns.
    • The final term will be devoted to project work.
    Topics Educationa1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • class
    • school
    • French
    • …
    verb + project
    • do
    project + noun
    • work
    preposition
    • project on
    See full entry
    2.

    planned work

  2.  
     a planned piece of work that is designed to find information about something, to produce something new, or to improve something
    • We worked on various projects together.
    • About 300 schools are involved in the project.
    • to fund/finance a project
    • to start/launch/initiate a project
    • to undertake/complete a project
    • a building/construction project
    • project to do something They've set up a research project to investigate the harmful effects of air pollution.
    • Work has begun on a project to build a new hospital.
    • project on something They are taking part in a project on reducing food waste.
    • a project manager/team
    Extra Examples
    • The company runs large construction projects.
    • He embarked on an ambitious project to translate all the works of Plato.
    • We are seeking funding for this project.
    • He needed some financial assistance from the bank to get his project off the ground.
    • The project aims to reduce homelessness.
    • The scheme will be extended throughout the country after a successful six-month pilot project.
    • The wedding became her pet project, and she spent hours organizing it.
    • The proposed reform project contains some interesting ideas.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • ambitious
    • big
    • huge
    • …
    verb + project
    • get off the ground
    • implement
    • initiate
    • …
    project + verb
    • aim to
    • be aimed at something
    project + noun
    • management
    • coordinator
    • director
    • …
    phrases
    • the aim of the project
    • somebody’s current project
    • somebody’s latest project
    • …
    See full entry
    3.

    set of aims/activities

  3. a set of aims, ideas or activities that somebody is interested in or wants to bring to people’s attention
    • The party attempted to assemble its aims into a focused political project.
    4.

    housing

  4. (also housing project)
     (North American English) a group of houses or apartments built for poor families, usually with government money
    • Going into the projects alone can be dangerous.
    5. Word Originlate Middle English (in the sense ‘preliminary design, tabulated statement’): from Latin projectum ‘something prominent’, neuter past participle of proicere ‘throw forth’, from pro- ‘forth’ + jacere ‘to throw’. Early senses of the verb were ‘plan’ and ‘cause to move forward’.
See project in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee project in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: project
